The SAP Web Dispatcher (SWD) component is used as a load balancer for SAP traffic among the SAP application servers.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/reference-architectures/sap/sap-netweaver
questions.question_text:
You deploy an SAP environment on Azure.
You need to ensure that incoming requests are distributed evenly across the application servers.
What should you use?

discussion.content:
N N Y
1. N between Region HSR Async
2. N Standard LB (Not Basic LB)
3. Cross Region for SAP application Server (ASR) used for replication
I think it's Y N N

N As Hana3 should be in Async due to cross -region setup, 
N Standard LB required for Apps
N for ASR should be on same region

comments.content: elaborate plz how basic lb can be used to implement high availability for backend of 2 different availability zone\set app services [p.2]

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The 30TB roughly 6-7 days or more if the network not stable.
Azure Data Box for fast data transfer.

questions.question_text:
You have an on-premises SAP NetWeaver development landscape that contains the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You have a 500-Mbps ExpressRoute circuit between the on-premises environment and a virtual network.

You plan to migrate the landscape to Azure.

What should you include in the solution?

choices.B: Microsoft System Center 2019 - Data Protection Manager (DPM 2019)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Option D is not a solution to the problem because enabling virtual network private endpoints only provides private connectivity between your virtual network and the Azure service, which can help to secure the traffic and prevent it from traversing the public internet. However, it does not address the issue of network saturation on the ExpressRoute circuit when backing up to Azure Blob storage. So correct option is C.

comments.content: With service endpoints, you are preventing the internet-bound traffic for Azure Blob Storage to avoid going over the Express Route (since quad "0" is advertised from on-prem).

questions.question_text:
You have an SAP environment on Azure.

Your on-premises network uses a 1-Gbps ExpressRoute circuit to connect to Azure. Private peering is enabled on the circuit. The default route (0.0.0.0/0) from the on-premises network is advertised.

Whenever backups are copied to Azure Blob storage, the ExpressRoute circuit is saturated.

You need to resolve the issue without modifying the ExpressRoute circuit. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

What should you do?

choices.A: Create a user-defined route that redirects traffic to the Blob storage
choices.C: Change the backup solution to use a third-party software that can write to the Blob storage

questions.question_text:
You have an SAP landscape on Azure that uses SAP HANA.

You perform a daily backup of HANA to Azure Blob Storage and retain copies of each backup for one year.

You need to reduce the backup storage costs.

What should you implement?

discussion.content:
C. A storage access tier.

Explanation:

To reduce the backup storage costs, you can move the backup files from the hot tier to the cool tier or the archive tier of the Azure Blob Storage. These tiers provide lower-cost storage for data that is not frequently accessed.

So, you should implement a storage access tier to move the HANA backups from hot to the cool tier or the archive tier. By doing this, you can save on storage costs while still retaining the backup copies for one year. A stored access policy is used to grant shared access to your storage account. Recovery Services Vault backup policy is used for backup and disaster recovery operations.

choices.B: a Recovery Services Vault backup policy
